text: the wild borderlands of malaysia where
migrant dreams of a promised land didn't
just vanish in the mist they were
crushed into the ground reinga muslims
fled persecution in myanmar and were
brought to these camps but the men who
promised to save them held them hostage
instead they would beaten tortured raped
and many were killed we're in the deep
jungle now on the Malaysian Thai border
and this is the area that holds the
darkest of Secrets there are more than
40 camps believed to be in this area I'm
standing in one of them it's very
makeshift there are bits of woods a few
twigs tied together but very little
shelter very little to protect people
and yet some people were kept in these
areas for as long as two years there are
more than 40 camps like this believed to
be hidden in these woods nearly a
hundred and forty bodies have already
been recovered and the prediction is
that there could be hundreds more buried
somewhere in this jungle we've met some
of those held in these camps Abdul Hakim
staggered out of the jungle this week
with just a pair of shorts to his name
he'd been held for an astonishing two
years in the jungle as the police closed
in the traffickers fled and the migrants
escaped Abdul Hakim has the face of a
haunted man he was starved beaten and
tortured at the end of this month I
would have been two years in the camp we
couldn't pay the ransom money so we were
tortured and kept there they poured
boiling oil on us sometimes the traffic
has hanged people a lot of people died
the place was covered with graves a lot
of people died
and the memories will be with them
forever
rashida loves her baby daughter but the
little girl will always remind her of
the jungle camps where she was raped by
so many men she doesn't know who I his
partner is they beat and killed the boys
and raped the girls who couldn't give
them money life is really bad in Mayan
ma and we can't survive there that's why
we left but it's hard to survive here -
when we go out the police take money
from us sometimes we were arrested
we thought that Malaysia would be better
but it's just the same so Rashida lives
in the shadows with other migrants
fleeing hardships at home risking
journeys at sea and suffering the
horrors of the jungle camps and for what
their non people in their promised land
and for those who survived the camps
there's neither dignity nor hope so
Rashida must beg on a bridge with her
baby and other migrants from Myanmar
just to survive
Malaysia doesn't class immerse refugees
and the UN stopped giving them papers
and has failed to help her they've
endured the worst humanity can sink to
and yet still no one sees them and no
one wants like the impanel BBC News
Kuala Lumpur Malaysia
